Strong Character Development.Description: Develop each character’s history and what drives them. This includes their past experiences, family dynamics, and formative events that shaped their personality.
Plan how characters evolve throughout the story. This could involve overcoming personal flaws, adapting to new situations, or experiencing significant growth or change.
Ensure characters are consistent in their actions and reactions, but also complex enough to avoid being predictable or one-dimensional.
Create characters that readers can relate to or empathize with, even if they are set in a fantastical or unfamiliar world.

Vivid World-Building.Description: Incorporate sights, sounds, smells, and textures to make the world feel tangible.
Outline the rules, traditions, and social norms of the world. This includes political systems, religious beliefs, and social customs.
Describe the physical landscape and how it affects the story and the characters. This could be a bustling city, a remote village, or an alien planet.
If applicable, define the rules and limitations of magic or technology in the world.

Engaging Plot.Description: Establish a central conflict and build tension around it. This could be character vs. character, character vs. self, character vs. society, etc.
Introduce unexpected developments that keep the story unpredictable and interesting.
Build up to a satisfying climax where the main conflict is confronted, followed by a resolution that ties up the story’s loose ends.

Emotional Depth.Description: Explore the internal struggles and conflicts of characters to create an emotional connection with the reader.
Use actions, reactions, and dialogues to convey emotions rather than simply stating them.
Create situations and dilemmas that evoke empathy and emotional investment from the reader.

Cultural and Historical Accuracy.Description: Conduct thorough research to accurately depict the cultures and historical settings you’re writing about.
Consider consulting with cultural or historical experts to ensure respectful and accurate representation.
Be mindful of avoiding stereotypes and presenting nuanced, respectful portrayals.

Innovative Narrative Techniques.Description: Experiment with telling the story out of chronological order.
Use different characters’ perspectives to provide a broader understanding of the story.
Employ narrators whose credibility is questionable, adding intrigue and complexity.

Appropriate Language and Style.Description: Tailor your language complexity, tone, and style to suit your intended audience.
Maintain a consistent narrative voice and style throughout the story.
Balance the use of dialogue and descriptive language to suit the genre and audience preferences.
